oh man, this is truly relatable. I once worked on a project that any version change in ~4 dependancies lead to a catastrophic failure or, "version hell". Basically, the incompatibilities was a seemingly infinite loop of correction.

Agreed though - julias compat stuff although pretty nice because things "tend to just work" is a little nightmarish. Reminds me of linux upgrades 10 years ago. every 1/10 updates bricks the environment.

text:
its not the environments, its just dealing with compat issues. Like "upgrade turing to use good syntax" oop now "diffeq exploded" upgrade diffeq, "can't upgrade diffeq because of juno"? who uses juno still? ask devs for fix "thats because of progressbar.jl".

or "upgrade CSV", lets go use pkg X, "sorry now pkg Y cannot be used". delete pkg Y. Now I can't do my project. Looks like I'm writing X on my own - oh well it was small anyways.

text:
its good that there's such strong coordination but it does scare me because... if someone leaves, or changes jobs, graduates, etc like LightGraphs - well, it will take roughly a month before incompat kills a library...

Incompat + frequent changes in packages to core syntax makes for a rough ride.

Do I have a better idea? Not really.. Maybe allow "Pkg add pkgname -UNSAFE" which will just ignore compat and try to load the code? bad idea right... Does it make the language unusable - not at all. Does it make it way more usable for the developers of the pkgs being used - exponentially(when there is a problem).

text: I was also sceptical about compat bounds at the beginning, but then I came to realise that they prevent potential runtime incompatibilities, which honestly looks like a great thing to me. The downside is that sometimes (often?) the incompatibilities are only potential, so updating the compat bounds is much hassle for little gain
